commentBody:
We are getting more formal. We have exchanged Friday's SUNDRESS for today's TEA DRESSES.

That was an ADDED BONUS.

Thanks, Joe.
Wow... 20 ten-letter answers and no clunkers!  I winced a bit at OVERABOUND but it's fine.
A very pleasant challenge that felt/solved like 5 puzzles; NE followed by SW, then center, SE and finally NW corner.

Should actually have read ‚ÄúBird whose name is CORRECTLY spelled‚Ä¶

Then, kahak≈ç, with diacritic over ‚Äòo‚Äô and no ‚Äòs‚Äô since no ‚Äòs‚Äô in Hawaiian alphabet.

But WAY cool to see this attempt

Interesting grid.
Wouldn‚Äôt it be fun if the long answers all read counterclockwise around the pinwheel? So the NE block would be upside down and the NW block backwards.

I can hear you now:
BAH!
LISTEN HERE!
WE‚ÄôRE SO DEAD!

But just maybe:
ADDED BONUS!

"Hey, what's with this new concert hall?"
"Now you listen here!"

(Posting this was a sound decision.)

NW and SE were Saturday sticky for me, which I appreciated.  Clue for NOT A was my favorite (once I finally got it) out of many good ones.  Always nice to see Joe‚Äôs name in the byline.

If anyone has done the 4/1/05 puzzle and can explain the (April Fool‚Äôs) gimmick to me, I‚Äôd appreciate it!
how many languages do we need to know to solve an English language crossword?

What a weird puzzle for me.

The NW, NE and middle quadrants were strangely easy - I solved them in what must have been Tuesday time.

However, the SW and SE quadrants were just impossible, for me. UTNEREADER? Oyez? Antonyms in an unidentified language? (I actually know HAI from Japanese commentary to climbing competitions, but I had no idea what its antonym may be). Also, HADES being *hot*? The Greeks and Romans envisioned their afterlife as cold and damp - totally unlike the hell of Christianity. Hades being hot is the equivalent of hell freezing over (possibly with pigs flying overhead). And there were more of these arcane mysteries. I needed loads of lookups to get a foothold there, which personally made the puzzle annoying more than anything.

I'm not a fan of Mr Shortz's editing since his return, and this feeling is getting stronger every week.
Indoor, not indoors??

Great puzzle, and what a lovely grid, whirlpool center or some kid doing cartwheels, which makes for those beautiful quartet of four-stackers, quite the feat, and good way of dealing with that awkward "altho" -- a word so uncrossworthy that even typing it out made me cringe. And the masterful stetson cluing, and the nice puzzpair (cf Sir Lewis of Asheville) "Listen here" and "Good ole boy." (To be honest, I'd spell it good ol' boy and it grated on me a bit, but I can live with it). And the cluing for HAI was ridiculous. I bet even Bill in Yokohama was going What the Hades for that clue!
Private agreement -- loved that one, too. Yes SIR.

It's good to see the Utne Reader here in its full name. So often we just get the Utne. You know? I've never looked at it. I never even think about it, even when I'm searching for alternative media (I'm getting pretty sick of mainstream media for its superficial coverage of worrisome events -- I'm looking at you, Gray Lady!), and I have no idea what its purpose would be in the current cultural discourse. All I know is that the owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, Bob Nutting, is apparently also the owner of the Utne Reader. He is the worst skinflint MLB owner imaginable. Every time we have an up and comer, off he goes next season to the Yankees -- we're their triple-A farm team. Thanks a lot Bob, see you in Hades!

Fine puzzle, imho.

I suspect it's going to be deemed Monday/Tuesday easy.  

I think maybe I'll avoid the comments today.  

You can thank me later.

Can‚Äôt believe double TIME got through the editing process unscathed (TIMEPIECES, PASSEDTIME). I really doubted the lower one until the crosses confirmed it. This is not like the Thursday puzzle which did it on purpose.

Oyez, this was CLUED SERTA CLASSICARly, EASTTOWEST,  ALTHO that DEPENDS on what CHEW want.  LISTENHERE,  I'd go on, but it's PASSED my bed TIME, and I'm OUTTA ideas.  EYREally must go.  BON SAI !!

Thanks, Joe.  I just polished off the last of a pint of Jamoca Almond Fudge, and this was an ADDEDBONUS.
Was stuck in the SE corner because I was convinced AnEn was the answer to 50D. Can‚Äôt get attached to my possibly wrong answers!

Suitable Saturday.  Hard enough but not all that hard.

Ranch dressing was a pretty great clue.  Overabound was a pretty terrible answer.  I credit my devotion to It's a Wonderful Life for being familiar with Oyez!  Added to one to make zero took me a minute.

Fun puzzle. Still prefer themed.  :)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
This one felt like an accomplishment

WastED too much TIME with wasted in the SE, which was my toughest area, but I enjoyed the puzzle and the time spent. 

My favorite was the ranch dressing clue for STETSONHAT, followed by private agreement for YESSIR. 

"Big blanket makers" for SNOWSTORMS was cute too and thankfully had nothing to do with quilts...  üòâ Har!  

All of it felt fresh and fun to me!  Thankful for another fun puzzle! 

Lately, I fear I'm absorbing myself a bit too deeply in puzzles in an effort to escape things, which is fine in balance, but shouldn't be OVERABOUNDing. I'll get my bearings but in the meantime, I'm glad for the pleasant diversions! Cheers to the weekend!

For the longest time I had 'AN EN' as the answer to what had to be added to one to make zero.   I was so sure it was true I kept it well beyond its 'best by' time and consequently took a shade over an hour to do this, worthy, puzzle.

I am genuinely perplexed by 50D [What's added to one to get zero?] is NOTA.

I thought by typing it out, it would come to me.  But it hasn't.

Maybe after I hit submit?
‚ÄòWe‚Äôre so dead‚Äô strikes again.  What‚Äôs that ? 3 times in the last couple of months ?  Can we take a break from using this for a  long time please ?
Enjoyed that‚Ä¶. Breezed through the top right section thanks to SWIT but struggled on the bottom right and top left‚Ä¶. Got there in the end‚Ä¶ an hour‚Ä¶ felt like a Saturday crossword!

Can someone please explain 24A to me? I don‚Äôt get it grammatically. Why would ‚ÄúTaking a hint?‚Äù (with a question mark) be CLUED (with a d)?

I‚Äôm clearly not taking this hint‚Ä¶

The ranch dressing clue was superb, by the way.
38A was so witty. Totally had me immersed in salad.

I found that challenging, and really enjoyed it. For a good while I had COWBOYHATS for the ‚Äúranch dressing‚Äù clue, and was patting myself on the back for my cleverness, but that of course didn‚Äôt last. Luckily, in NYC I live around the corner from the Stetson shop‚Ä¶

Crossword clue: Capital of Georgia.
My immediate answer: Tbilisi 
Wrong!

I keep forgetting this is a game not suited for people living outside the US...

Regarding 53D: ABDI is not an Arabic name you‚Äôd normally ever see used by Arabs, and it doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúservant of God‚Äù in Arabic. It means ‚Äúslave‚Äù or ‚Äúservant‚Äù‚Äîit would need to be Abdullah (or the like) to mean ‚Äúservant of God‚Äù in Arabic. While this name might exist in Turkish (and other languages), it doesn‚Äôt really make sense to call it an ‚ÄúArabic man‚Äôs name.‚Äù

Had plenty of fun solving this one. Though I have to admit, my total unfamiliarity with the UTNE READER made me stare at the SE for a long time before finally putting in those letters based on crosses. It seemed like it had to be a typo!

Took me about 15 minutes to do 90% of the puzzle then got stuck in the SE for an hour. A complete dead end. After lots and lots of playing around, I finally figured out GOODOLEBOY/ADORE and the rest fell into place pretty quickly. Probably been a year since I've taken over an hour on a non Sunday

Fun puzzle, thanks for that!

I got stuck for a while because I was a little too proud of my cleverness by adding "an en" to "one" to make "none" for zero (instead of NOTA). Held onto that for a little too long.

I was totally frozen in the SE (schoolmarm for GOODOLEBOY was unhelpful), but Sammy, Steven M. and Steven saved me. Thankyou. 

And I do like puzzle entries that send me careening down memory lanes‚Ä¶ TRAVEL VISA had me back in 1976, at a Romanian border crossing, a whole long train kept waiting for three hours while they decided what to do with a lone young American woman with that stamp in her passport.

Wow, this is indeed a most unusual and mesmerizing design. It is so perfectly symmetrical that you can just keep spinning it around and see the same pattern no matter which way you turn. I even solved it in a circular way, starting from EAST TO WEST. 

I love the abundance of 10-letter entries and clever wordplay. It all felt very fresh. 

Great job, Joe! All the time you spent was well worth it.

I misle
You misle
He/she/it misles

Good thing the NYT hasn't dropped the TQ

Beautiful gird design!

Typical tough Saturday workout for me, but a pretty amazing layout. All those 10 letter answers? - Nine debuts and ten others that have only appeared once or twice before. Don't recall seeing that much freshness in a while.

Anyway - a number of things I wasn't going to get from the clues and just had to work them out from the crosses. Just made for a nice challenge. 

A couple of interesting puzzle finds today.  I'll put those in a reply. 

...
PDQ

Fun themeless.  [This might come after the check] for MATE was a favorite.  

The NW should have been easy for me because I was able to fill in UTNE READER with no crosses, but it still put up a bit of a fight.  Getting NOT A made me groan and opened it up.
I liked the grid, and found it just right for a Saturday, so needed my usual amount of help for late week

Weird puzzle for me. Everything filled in very quickly aside from the inscrutable SE section which took me twice as long as the rest of the puzzle, bringing me in at 20% above average. Wish I knew what the heck UTNEREADER was. The T and N could have been any letters as far as I was concerned

In the SE I correctly had BONS and EYRE (despite the preponderance of orphans in Brit Lit), but incorrectly had BOOTY (for 47d Treasure) and GUFF (for 52d Flack). And with those 4 crosses, VANITY FAIR fit perfectly at 59a. That had to be correct for a publication of 10 letters matching so many crosses, right?  And then AMAL was surely correct for 53d (a name ending in AL, the beginning of Allah). It was just a shame that ‚ÄúAN EN‚Äù (which seemed like it must be the answer for 50d) didn‚Äôt fit üòÇ.

It took a long time to unwind that mess! ü§ì

Great puzzle! Completely stuck in the southeast and about to give up, but then got RIGUP which somehow illuminated GOODOLEBOY‚Ä¶ and that broke it open. (I really impressed myself; hope the Comments don‚Äôt say it was easy!)
Just as many others, the SE was quite the challenge. I finally thought of the Utne Reader and then the rest came to me.
As trade winds move east to west, so did my solve. Thanks, Joe Deeney!
Same as others ‚Äî I found the SE corner to be so much harder than the rest of the puzzle. Lovely though. Thank you!

Don‚Äôt you just love classic magazines?
Hanging out down at the cider mill,
leafing through old copies of The Apple Press‚Ä¶

A fun Saturday, though not much time passed.
A fun puzzle..clever fill..but pretty easy for a Saturday

I solved this under my average, but it was a hard solve.  I mean, without looking at a recipe I figured GRAM flour was correct.  It was only the APPLEPRESS that saved me.  Things started coming together with the STETSONHAT, which made me smile. 
Like everyone else, I struggled with the SE corner.  Like someone else said, I used to subscribe to UTNEREADER.  So that helped a bit.  But for the longest time I had OLD not OLE.

Fun solve today.  Beat my average by 4 minutes.

You just know it‚Äôs 
gonna be a fun ride 
when you open the grid
and count the black squares.

So much to fill!

Like a word buffet.
Love it.

Which parts did I dislike?

Not a one!

Hope you all have something really
unexpectedly lovely happen in your day today!

Oh. Well. Thing of beauty in so many ways. 

The elegant grid design, allowing for a spectacular 24 longs.  Longs bring the fun of guessing the answer with as few crosses as possible, and today ahas and ohos overabounded.  What a pleasure ride!

Pleasure also comes from answers and clues never or rarely before seen in the NYT puzzle. Listen to this incredible fact that I gleaned from XwordInfo data: 199 of the puzzle‚Äôs 225 squares belong to answers that have been in the Times puzzle only four times before or less.  That's practically 90% of this puzzles squares. 90%! Amazing!  

The freshness includes lovely debuts ADDED BONUS, APPLE PRESS, CLASSIC CAR, and even the make-me-smile quaint HOT AS HADES.

So, add spark to the fun of this puzzle.

Not to mention the pleasure that comes from wit in cluing, as seen in the clues for SNOWSTORMS, NOT A, STETSON HAT, and the marvelous [This might come after the check] for MATE.

I crow.  I know. I crow for Joe today, for this panoply of pleasure, this sweet outing flecked with beauty.  This one was special.  Bravo, sir, and thank you!

Was sailing along until the SE.  

ProPublica crossing with Amir were mistakes 1 and 2.  It's like that some Saturdays.

I enjoyed this one, not too tricky except for the magazine, the Southern expression, the company name and the bird.

Can it be that this crossword had no sports clues?
No rap or film stars?
That helps me such a lot.

I wondered - could 'entry form' could have something to do with a birth certificate?
Guessed correctly on ‚Äúutne reader‚Äù and had to look up the flour but after that everything just kind of fell into place. A very enjoyable, challenging but not too, Saturday puzzle.
Going to avoid Saturdays for the foreseeable future. This was miserable and felt like the constructor needed work on his cluing. Pass.

A proper workout and a bit like solving 4 minis.  This morning's rabbit hole was checking out ABDI, which I learned is related to Abdul.  Some ABDI's of note:

Abdi ƒ∞pek√ßi (1929‚Äì1979), Turkish journalist
Abdi Kassim, Zanzibari footballer
Abdi Pasha (disambiguation), various Ottoman people
Abdi Toptani (1864‚Äì1942), Albanian politician
Abdi Haji Yaris, Somali politician

This one is for @Andrzej after his complaint about gratuitously violent shows...the series "Foyle's War" about a detective chief inspector in the English coastal town of Hastings during WW II. I think it was a BBC production; available in USA via PBS (Public Broadcasting System). Touches on the fear of invasion, the Mosleyites, anti-foreigner hysteria, rationing, Land Girls, Dunkirk, children evacuated from London and much more.

Great puzzle.

I realized I had no idea what is in ranch dressing.... and then I realized it didn't matter. 

Nota one confused me for the longest time.

And I appreciate Joe Deeney's tip re flexibility in the long intersecting answers. I've been working on constructing xwords lately, and find it incredibly fun and satisfying .... until it isn't anymore-- when I reach a roadblock and have to start all over.

Kudos to the constructor for a great puzzle. It just kind of sang. And it took me half my average time, and I didn't need to turn on Autocheck.  I don't want to get too overconfident, though, as Saturdays are usually a bear for me.

TWENTY ten-letter words in a Saturday puzzle!?!
WoW!
Who could possibly complain about a puzzle like that???

[X-Phile timidly raises his hand.]
Did anyone else think that this grid felt like four (mega-)minis, plus a mini-mini in the middle?
Was it only me?
OK, I'll be quiet now.

Still I enjoyed the puzzle...but those nits are in me, and they just gotta get picked.

The first sign was the grid--vast swaths of white space....one might even have said, "Hoo, boy.  Blanks ABOUND."  Whether it is possible for something to OVERABOUND, now, that is another question.  

At one time DHubby and I owned a cider press (in aid of his wine-making) to deal with the bounteous harvest from my home orchard.  We did not call it an APPLE PRESS.  (One could press other fruits as well...)  

It has been quite some TIME since The UTNE READER made an appearance.

I have not always gladly embraced advances in home computers...and I once overheard PhysicsDaughter telling DHubby --in withering tones--"Dad, I think Mom is just a DOS person."
Ha ha.  (I found making the mouse behave to be very challenging.)
Love it when I get just the right clues here to finish without having to ruin my run!

Making one's own cider is a lot of fun.

Getting the ADDEDBONUS took a while but ko and I did it.

Thank you Joe
I was so sure we had gotten a Saturday rebus as I tried to scrunch in for 12D "It's so cool that our parents are acrobats!"

I finished the top half of the puzzle fairly quickly, but the bottom half was quite a challenge. I'm glad I'm not the only one who found the SE section especially tricky! 

"Western hat" instead of STETSON threw me off for a while, but having "an en" for 50D instead of NOTA really messed with my brain.
This was a great puzzle. Got stuck in a lot of places. Top right corner fell into place first. Lots of fun. Thanks!
As usual, the Saturday took me an hour. Is that good, bad or average? Nice if the app showed some stats to compare against.
Tangent of the day: Anyone interested in TIMEPIECES and horology should try the book I am reading now, ‚ÄúHands Of Time: A Watchmaker‚Äôs History‚Äù by Rebecca Struthers. It is a wonderful book.
Way too hard for me.
Can‚Äôt believe I solved the WHOLE thing. On first glance I thought, ‚ÄúNo way, Jos√©!‚Äù Not even one or two short fills that I could use as hooks. The only gimme that gave me hope was 22A: YES SIR.
Much fun wordplay here. My favorite was Stetson Hat, but Travel Visa was a close second.
if the criterion for POY depends on elegance, and not difficulty, this definitely a contender for F-S . Remind me come December.

Admirable construction and cluing. Almost all the answers are "gettable" through logical thinking, rather than accumulated knowledge. If you are giving up on this one, I hope you persevere.
Speaking of TIMEPIECES....my grandfather clock fell over and literally went to pieces the other day. Believe me - not a chance of repair. I am simply devastated.
Ok, this was genuinely easy.  I've been working my way back through the archives, now in the 20 teens, and have come to dread Saturdays as next to impossible.  This week's Friday was much harder.

Thought for sure there must be POODLE BOYS somewhere in the South.
But no.
Lot's of GOOD OLE BOYS however.

Great Puzzle!

A fantastic construction. Four quadruple stacks, and four additional ten-worders tying the grid together. And all twenty of these long entries were solid.

Didn't know CECE or ABDI, but the stacks supplied them for me.

Solved this unaided, but took more than half-an-hour. Outstanding puzzle!
Nice and easy ride.

I got really stuck with PASSED TIME as TIME had been already used in TIMEPIECES so I didn't think it would occur twice. 
This took me longer than any Saturday puzzle in memory. Thanks for the challenge.

The missing diacritic in 16A's clue, plus the odd pluralization, made me miss the answer on my first pass. It's a diacritic that saves a bit of ink and a bit of paper, but its cons include being too hard to type and too easy to leave out, cons it shares with the 'okina (and the Spanish tilde). The kahak≈ç represents a doubling of the vowel it is written over, and it would make better sense to write the vowel twice. https://bartssite.net/hawaiianspelling.html Granted, most people who don't know the word would mispronounce "kahakoo." Big deal! Call me kiilaueabart.

I've read 196 comments, and no one's asked about DRIP being a "cause of insomnia, maybe" so I'll go ahead and be the one, prepared for a big head slap. Grateful if someone could explain it. The only DRIPs that come to my mind are IV DRIPs and nose DRIPs. Yes, I'm thick as a brick this morning (cue Jethro Tull: https://youtu.be/hFYOcOBPkzg?si=6YzY4GHrZ4IzxKTn) Thank you to all who explained the dook NOTA, yet another low point which I had to get from the crosses. That said, my real downfall was the NW, with absolutely nothing coming to me, not even ATTA. I needed ADDED BONUS and APPLE PRESS from the column for the light to shine on everything else. Thank you, Mr. Deeply for so lovingly dedicating yourself to this puzzle. The shortcomings are all my own. It's a beautiful grid, and expertly CLUED. It's also alerted me to today being a day best served by avoiding anything that requires logic, thinking, or deducing. The Universe has spoken and I'll be [taking a hint.] Netflix and chill, here it come!
I see that the Strands thread I started about 6 hours ago has been taken down.  Curious if any of our "strandmates" noticed any unusual comment(s)?
A great mental workout!

It's so funny what is easy for some then others of us needs lots of help!

Here is how my week goes:

Monday: it's usually in my range of doable, no hints.

Tuesday:  I might have one sticking point, like a cross with two names I don't know.

Wednesday: I might use hints from the column, but I feel okay leaving my star gold because I did most of it on my own.

Thursdays: the dreaded possible rebus day!  I don't mind the rebus but I don't know always when they are in play so it's almost always going to be a heads up from the column!  I'm mixed bag -- the more I've done, the more I can fill in natively and feel okay claiming the win, but there's some point that I've used enough hints from column and comments I'll run autocheck to not get a gold star. (Am I weird there's a level of help that the integrity kicks in whether I've earned gold or not? Probably!)

And then later in the week, puzzles like this that even with hints I turn on autocheck and know I'm not doing this one with my ability at all!

And yes, there are times I have autocheck on and run the vowels and fill those in and then figure out the answer, and if that doesn't do it, run common letters like t, s, r.

I admire those of you who tackle these and say how easy they are as if it were a Monday solve for me, but I know I'll never be one of y'all.

That's okay, I still have fun meeting the challenge at my ability level even if it's not up to par!

Happy weekend, fellow puzzle solvers!

"As the Crier speaks, the nine Justices stride through openings in the curtains and move to their places. The Crier chants the call for silence: ‚ÄúOYEZ! OYEZ!! OYEZ!!!‚Äù From the centuries that Anglo-Norman or ‚Äúlaw French‚Äù was the language of English courts, the word for ‚ÄúHear ye!‚Äù survives."

From Google.
Not much to add to the earlier comments, a disadvantage of west coast living, but to say that is remarkable how much wasted time results from an incorrect but otherwise perfect 10 letter answer.

Quick technical question: How do you keep track of whether your comments have received replies? I just sent a message in the support chat to ask if there's a way to turn on notifications for comment replies but was told this feature doesn't exist. So how do you know when you've received a reply so you can respond? 

(The checkbox at the bottom of the comment form is only for notification of when a comment is published or when a journalist replies.)

I'm sure lots of people have already said it, but I loved this puzzle. At first thought it was going to be impossible, but I kept at it. So many wonderfully clever clues -- "Stetson hat" was an utterly delicious figure-out!
My brain was INBADSHAPE today. Tricky throughout but learned about Utne Reader.

So nervous today! We have a silly tradition in the family that however you do on the crossword on your birthday determines how good your year will go. My son‚Äôs bday is today, so I had to work EXTRA hard to get this one right! üòÉüòÇ
I groaned when I got my first look at the puzzle, but managed to complete it in my usual time.  Looking forward to Sunday, which for me in LA is at 3 pm Saturday.
50D I thought was ANEN (unsure if ‚Äúen‚Äù is a valid spelling of the letter N). But NOTA works just about as well.

Whoof, this one got me. It's always a challenge when the various sections are siloed off from one another, and these ones were about as separated as I remember seeing. Still, I was able to work my way through up until the SE corner. Without much crossing help, I finally had to look up UTNEREADER - I knew I'd recognize the name from past puzzles, but I couldn't bring it to mind. That was enough to get me the rest of the way. It was a good time even if I needed some help, kudos to the constructor on besting me!
I loved the Utne Reader back in the day pre-online media availability.  It was a great way to access the most compelling content from across the more niche publications.  Surprised to see it here!

SE corner was tough for me. 

I liked TIMEPIECES and TEADRESSES.  

I also got stuck on adding an ‚Äún‚Äù to ‚Äúone‚Äù on 50 down which made the SE corner all the harder.
Finished in 10 seconds below average. Fun puzzle.

Nicely chewy puzzle, one of those like five separate puzzles in one. STETSON HAT got me connected into the center portion.

Quick-scrolling through the comments, I don't see a post on today's Strands puzzle. Hard to believe there was anything about  it that deserved ye olde emu kick-out.
Strands #370
‚ÄúTwo thumbs up‚Äù
üí°üîµüîµüü°
üîµüîµüîµ

The expression "Hot as Hades" would have been completely unknown to me, as a Canadian, were it not for the excellent Billie Holiday song "I Must Have That Man": https://youtu.be/o2wfHTYRIbE?si=OLZiJq1zMCotb5np
My new thing is to put in the first word that comes to mind.  BUTTERMILK and FLORIDAMAN did me no favors today! However, 5 weeks in Japan sure did!  Hai!

was really hoping that the answer to 50D was:
ONEN... itself an anagram for NONE.
50 Down was terrible. NOTA? How about NOT A real answer?

I don‚Äôt know why I always find the Saturday puzzles a chore compared to the rest of the week‚Äôs. I think something about the obscurity of the factual clues means that when there are actual clever clues I‚Äôm all worn out and just grunt at them rather than appreciate them. Looking over it now there are some lovely clues; just seems to take forever to get to them on Saturdays.
@Barry Ancona Sun dresses are proof that there is a God and he wants us to be happy.

@Dave S 

Which must be way any woman can wear a sun dress to any Christian church, especially a Catholic one. Oh, wait.
Thank you autocorrect for making why into way...

@Bill in Yokohama 
I had pretty much the same experience, but in a different order. Mine was NW followed by NE, then SW, Center, and finally SE. It felt so strange to have sections of the puzzle completely filled in while others were completely empty! An unusual solve for sure.

@Cat Lady Margaret I miss the NYT novelty puzzles that did this, sort of. I think it was called Spiral.  I also like vowel-less puzzles and the clueless puzzle. Those went away for us merely digital subscribers.

@Mike 

I thought I heard about a pool hall with good cue sticks.

I felt bad but I'll chalk it up to experience.

Good thing I have deep pockets.

I thinking get it re the 4/1/05 puzzle.  Thought there was a second layer I was missing, but now I realize there probably was not.  It‚Äôs a fun puzzle.  I am very fond of Friday puzzles from the aughts.  I thought I‚Äôd done them all but this evening I realized I had somehow overlooked April and May 2005 when I was going backward through the Archives. They feel like an ADDED BONUS.
* I think I . . .

@Puzzlemucker

Just did that puzzle. Won‚Äôt give me the song, so maybe I‚Äôm missing the right rebus and I don‚Äôt know how to complete, but I think it is how the puzzle ‚Äúfools‚Äù you.

@Darren 
Found a Reddit discussion from a year ago that says it will solve on your phone but not on laptop. That is, unless you hit Reveal for those three squares.

I was even able to paste in black squares using the rebus button, but the clock is still running.

The answer key showed it with slashes, but those did not work, either.

@Puzzlemucker I did that puzzle. Spoilers!!




 There are three Ss scattered through the grid which turn twelve answers to gibberish. If they were black the answers would make sense. But since it ran before wordplay started I don't know how they got there. I can't imagine I would have entered them, they make no sense. Maybe when we entered 43 across they filled into the grid
@Keith Feel free to stick to early week puzzles which have both easier vocabulary and trivia.

@Keith 

You don't really have to know any, most of the time.  Almost all foreign language clues are fairly crossed and often can be sussed out logically.  Note first and foremost, I'm not calling you out; I'm explaining a strategy to get you over the finish line next time.

For the Japanese clue, you don't have to know foreign opposites.  You just have to know what may be the one Japanese word that Anglophones know that hasn't been borrowed into English like "karate" and "sushi".  That word is HAI,meaning"yes", and it has an opposite. Now you know two words, HAI and "iie" (no).  Believe me, I didn't know the answer from the clue.  I just thought, "What three-letter Japanese words do I know that have an opposite?"  And I could only think of one.

If I couldn't think of any, the crosses were fair and would have helped me.

The Spanish clue might not make any sense to anyone who doesn't know any Spanish, but again, you're limited to three-letter words, and the crosses are fair.  If you can't reason the word out from the clue, you have a fair chance of getting the three crosses.

If you can't get those three crosses (in either example), you've got a bigger issue than knowing a couple of foreign words.

BON VIVANT is borrowed from French, but its use as an English term is well established.  You just have to know--or figure out--that both words are pluralized in French.  BONS is apparently needed to make that area work, and is likely unavoidable.

Hope this helps!

@Steve L 

I like how you try to bring order to chaos - but how do we explain Georgia? I have another theory.

We polonize words in several basic ways:

First, we apply our spelling to how foreign words sound to us, when it's simple enough and produces a name that looks OK in Polish. Hence Teksas, Kalifornia and Floryda.

Second, we translate stuff that can be translated, hence Nowy Jork (which combines way one with way two), and especially P√≥≈Çnocna/Po≈Çudniowa Karolina/Dakota.

Third, we may leave alone words which have no Polish counterpart but are easy enough for us to pronounce, because your spelling makes sense in Polish, too: Alaska, Dakota.

That leaves the question: why do we *not* polonize some stuff? My theory is: some words have no Polish counterparts, and their English spelling does not lend itself to Polish rules. Take Connecticut - in Polish I would have to phonetically write that down as Konektikat, which looks really, REALLY weird. Same with Iowa - Ajo≈Ça. What is that even? It hurts my Polish eyes. So we just let things be, even though the English spelling is incompatible with Polish pronunciation.

And maybe we stick to Georgia as the US state to avoid confusion with Gruzja, Georgia the country?

@Andrzej 
King GEORGE (the third of that title) sent leader Oglethorpe to colonize the lands that were named in his own honor.  You can visit Fort Frederica on St. Simon's Island along the Georgia coast!  John and Charles Wesley visited there for a time.
Compared to French settlements to the West and the Jamestown (and even the Plymouth) colonies farther North, GA was late to the party!  

(In 8th grade, one was forced to study Georgia history.)

GRAHAM crackers were inspired by the teachings of an early-19th century preacher named Sylvester Graham, whose main thrust was that God designed people to live their lives without enjoyment.  

Wikipedia elaborates further:

He believed that minimizing pleasure and stimulation of all kinds, including the prevention of masturbation, coupled with a vegetarian diet anchored by bread made from wheat coarsely ground at home, was how God intended people to live, and that following this natural law would keep people healthy. Towards that end, Graham introduced the world's first graham wafer product. It was a dull, unsifted flour biscuit baked by Graham himself.
----

Keep at it. It can take years. At this point I almost never leave a white space on any day of the week unless it represents a cross of two clues from sports, most music written after 1975, or geography. That was not always the case, by far.

@Beth 

"what's the point of @ing people if they'll never be notified you responded to them?"

The comment system does it automatically at the top of a reply, I guess so that replies are "conversational". But as you can see with my comment, there's no way to show _which_ comment of multiple by the same poster one is referencing!

In the body of a reply, when referring to other commenters, I usually include the @ so the handle is defined (as opposed to being a means of tagging that person).

@Barry Ancona 
This clue does not hold water. If you add an 'N' to the word one at its beginning then you have 'None'.  That would give you 'an en' as John StL said.  

But 'Not a one' doesn't work exclusively for the clue as written.  If it is not a one it doesn't have to be zero!  A two is also 'not a one', so is a seven, or a twenty seven.  Just because it is not a one doesn't require it be zero. 

I solved it be entering every letter in alphabetical order til the 'T' gave me the Congratulations jingle, as I'd completed the entire rest of the puzzle.

He presents the clue as a math-analysis statement.  But he means instead the colloquial expression 'Not a one'.  So for that  usage the clue should be presented more like this:  
'___ _ one', i.e. none.

Ken Henschel

Ken,

This is a crossword puzzle, not math class. A crossword entry does not have to be the only possible answer to the clue. We're not here to prove theorems or solve equations.

*One* of the things "not a one" can mean is "nothing," and nothing can mean zero.

Whatever else "not a one" can mean is a nice discussion, and in a crossword it may lead to misdirection, but that's why they call these puzzles. The clue is valid.


 

"Not a one" means none
